We SKIM along the w in and around looming glacial cliffs-- The top of an iceberg pushes through the water's surface. Carved into the ice is a single mammoth word:
We continue past, along the ocean, and discover: An old fishing boat, the RAINBOW WARRIOR, holds position outside a small natural harbor. All lights extinguished.

ARCTIC OCEAN, NEAR THE 170th PARALLEL ON DECK: Eco-warriors peer through high-powered binocular video cameras. Among them: An intense WOMAN. A RUSSIAN MA with a scraggly beard. A surly BLOND MAN, who monitors a counter. All wear heavy parkas against the gray cold.

Can anyone make out the registry? WHAT THEY ARE WATCHING: A distant SALVAGE SHIP, moored in the harbor. Its hoist is swung out over the sea. Flood li illumine salvage divers as they submerge with hoist cable
Not me. Bojemoi...I think my eyeballs are frozen.
It's blacked out. Whatever they're up to, it's no goddamn good. Near the salvage ship, the divers guide the cable as the engines begin working, winching the cable up.
(looks up from Geiger counter) Background radiation is nearly a hundred times normal. They're harvesting reactor cores. They must be.
We don't know that. There's no evidence of--
(pointedly accusing) There's a thirty-year-plus history of Soviets dumping nuclear waste and old reactors into the Kara, the Barents, the Sea of Japan--
(amused) I swear, I was not there. I had a cold.
So why not the Arctic? Who knows how many of these graveyards there are?

Something's wrong! The two men re-focus on the salvage ship-- --where crewmen race across the deck. Divers scramble ont platform. A klaxon sounds-- Suddenly the GEIGER COUNTER SQUEALS, readings off the sca The Blond Man drops it, startled.
Shit! The sea begins to BOIL beneath the salvage ship.

Chain reaction! Grab tight-- The sea ERUPTS. The salvage ship is HEAVED into the air. disappears in a FIERY EXPLOSION-- The shock wave rocks the Rainbow Warrior violently. Peopl scramble as the deck tips. Huge chunks of ice peel off th cliffs, crash into the sea, onto the ship. With a cry, th Blond Man falls overboard. Smoke pours from below decks. The Geiger counter calls out an uninterrupted staccato. The Russian Man stumbles blindly through the chaos, grasp  deck rails.
...I can't see...Claus? Martha? Help me!
Look at that! The snow can't burn! It can't burn! Near where the remains of the salvage ship, the snow is i on fire--an eerie sight. A fissure has opened up in the glacier, still expanding.
Oh my god!
(stumbles toward her) Martha? Where are you? What is happening? The Woman stares toward the shore.
It's bleeding... RED-BLACK FLUID flows out of the fissure, into the sea. T fluid steams in the chill Arctic air. Turning the ocean b red.
The Earth is bleeding...
The window is wide open. The curtains don't move. A fan l pointlessly, aimed toward the bed--which is empty. Sudden the mattress JUMPS, bumped from beneath. There is a giggl
I thought we got on the floor to cool off.
Oh, gee. I'm sorry. I'll stop.
Just an observation. No  complaint. Please, continue. The phone RINGS shrilly.
Dammit. KEITH LLEWELLYN pulls himself out from under the bed to a the phone. He is mid-thirties with a charming smile.

Dr. Llewellyn. (listens; dismayed) How soon? Okay, okay...I'll be ready. (beat) What? Oh, of course. JILL LLEWELLYN has emerged from beneath the bed. A woman high intelligence and strong passions. Keith extends the
For you.
(takes the phone) Dr. Llewellyn. How soon? Yes, I can be ready. She hangs up the phone. Looks at Keith, dismayed.
The Arctic. Both of us.
I hate cold weather. Jill pulls him to her. Smiles at him.
Could be our last chance to be warm for a while... He smiles back at her, leans in to kiss her-- BRIGHT LIGHT FLOODS THE ROOM. The curtains are blown back helicopter settles down outside the window.
Now the government gets efficient?

At an upstairs window, TINA LLEWELLYN looks out. 15 years bright and aching to test boundaries. She peers at the helicopter. A CUTE PILOT guides the ‘copter to the ground. Across the street, a NEIGHBOR and his SON emerge from the house to investigate the noise. Prop wash blows loose a p plastic lawn flamingo. The Neighbor grabs for it. The rotors wind down. The Cute Pilot goes over a checklis looks up--and his eyes go wide.
Oh, man. Tina is coming toward the ‘copter, wearing T-shirt, tight an underage smile.

(extends his wrists to co-pilot) Just slap the cuffs on me now and be done with it. Tina reaches the cockpit. The Cute Pilot looks down at hi clipboard, very aware that looking anywhere else could re a morals charge.
Hi.
Good evening, miss. Kinda late for you to be up, isn't it?
I'm old enough. Across the street, the neighbor clutches his flamingo.
I don't care how high-up they are...Ever since they moved in, it's one disruption after another.
(staring at Tina)  I don't mind. Jill and Keith exit the house, carrying parkas and small duffels. Jill sees Tina--and hurries to her. The Cute Pil still studies his clipboard.
Tina...this is hardly an appropriate fashion statement. Keith drapes his parka around Tina's shoulders.

That depends on what I'm trying to say. The Cute Pilot chuckles--and then meets Keith's glare. Refocuses on his clipboard. Jill herds Tina toward the ho into the shelter of the porch and the doorway. Keith foll
God, unruffle, mom. It's no big deal--
I don't want any problems while we're gone. It'll only be a few days, tops.
I could go stay with Aunt Julia.
Aunt Julia's rarely home long. We don't want you to be by yourself-- Tina lets out a loud snort of a laugh.

--in New York. In Manhattan. Here, you're safe. (spreads his arms; a knowing understatement) Nothing unusual ever happens here. She smiles at the sight of him, the helicopter behind him lawn gearing up to take off.
Really--you'll be okay?
I'll be fine, dad. Go on.
Okay. Well...bye. He kisses her forehead. Takes his parka, heads out toward helicopter. Pauses to call to the Neighbor.
Will you keep an eye on things for us, Mr. Torkleson? The Neighbor's son answers immediately, almost gratefully
Yes!
(scowls at his son) Yes...no problem. Jill regards Tina, who looks away sullenly. Jill smiles ruefully.
Use some of the money in the bread box to buy a bathrobe, huh?

Whatever, mom. Jill looks at her. A perfunctory kiss--neither is comfort with it--and then Jill heads for the helicopter. The helicopter lifts. Jill sees Tina standing in the shad the porch. She looks very small and alone.

An C-130 transport with ski treads lands on a makeshift airstrip. Temporary shelters have been set up. The Rainbo Warrior is now mostly submerged. Jill and Keith emerge from the plane, make final adjustme their biohazard suits, heavy-duty coveralls with full hoo visor, hood slung back. Keith has a thin file folder. A young captain, TUCKER, peachfuzz mustache failing to ma  look older, meets them. He also wears a biohazard suit.
(greets each) Dr. Llewellyn! Dr. Llewellyn! I'm Tucker! Tucker takes Keith's arm, snaps something onto the sleeve
Radiation badge. If it goes red, consider yourself cured of cancer.
And dead, of course.
(as Tucker snaps a badge on her) But a healthy kind of dead.

(points with the file) What the hell have you found here, anyway? Tucker leads them toward the fissure. Ahead, bio-suited w wheel large storage drums out of the fissure. seats a lid; Jill stops him, peers inside.
This is peculiar soup...
Early analysis is pretty weird... It has a marked resemblance to amniotic fluid. We think.
Amniotic fluid?
Like in a womb?
Uh-huh...well, not really... there're some complex compounds... and a heavy barbiturate presence. We think. One worker re- Jill scowls, her mind suddenly very far away as she cont this information.
I know one of you Doctors Llewellyn is a bio-chemist... Despite being addressed, Jill does not answer. Keith step
That would be the pretty one.
We have a lab set up if you'd like to... But Jill is already moving off with the worker wheeling t barrel.

I think she'd like to. Hey, Jill! She turns. He hands her the file. lLeans to kiss her chee she's already reading the folder as she walks away. Keith glances at Tucker, shrugs. Tucker smiles. Pulls on hood, seals it. Keith does, too. Tucker gestures to follo slips into the fissure--

Keith and Tucker clamber down ladders anchored to the gla deep into the fissure, into: A huge cavern, carved out of ice and earth, lit by a stri bare lights that stretch away in both directions. The wall opposite the fissure is imposing and strange, ma of crevices and finely textured stone, markedly different the ice wall and ceiling. A bio-suited workcrew pumps the red-black fluid into stor drums. Tucker leads Keith, slogging through shin-deep flu
The entire cavern was filled with this stuff-- Suddenly there is a LOW RUMBLE--a small TREMOR. Ice sifts from above. Lights flicker. Keith glances at Tucker.  10

An avalanche somewhere. Or the sea floor shifting. The blast that opened this up was some pretty mean shake-and-bake. Something beyond Tucker has drawn Keith's attention: appa it is a smaller cavern. Inside are weirdly regular rows o stalagmite and stalactites. Keith moves inside, examining Tucker stands outside.
This is the strangest stalactite formation I've ever seen...
Those aren't stalactites. Keith gives him a puzzled look, starts to really examine "cavern'--
(enjoys the revelation) They're teeth. Keith's eyes widen--he suddenly sees what's been in front all along: he's inside a giant mouth. He scrambles out to beside Tucker.
My God...my God. He takes in the mouth. Touches the strangely-textured ‘wa
And this isn't stone...is it? It's petrified or something--but this is skin. (he turns to Tucker) It's skin.

It's skin. We think. But it might as well be stone, for all the good we've done trying to get a tissue sample...we broke three diamond drill bits on it-- Keith clambers up, over the open mouth, caught up in the

This is incredible...the preservation is extraordinary... Mammoths and the like found frozen show much more decay. Even the  Alps ice man-- 10. He stops. Stares down the length of the body. The string of lights is more than a football field in len
How big is this...this..? Tucker climbs up beside him.
Two hundred forty-seven feet... There's also a tail, but how long that is we can't tell yet...
Two hundred and forty-seven feet? (he looks again) Two hundred and forty-seven feet...so much for seismosaurus and ultrasaurus...It is a dinosaur, isn't it? Tucker shrugs--then nods, grinning.
We think. Another TREMOR, bigger this time. More ice rains down. Th lights flicker. Go out, plunging the cavern into DARKNESS
Shit...wait a sec... He snaps on a flashlight, illumining the two men, still s on the beast's muzzle.

(bellows an order) Nobody move 'til we get the lights back on. (to Keith) We don't need anyone tripping over some giant dinosaur nuts in the dark or something... (another order) And let's get the lights back on, shall we? Thank you! Behind the two men, unnoticed by them, there is MOVEMENT- 11  12 The monster's EYELID OPENS, ten feet across. A second, semi-transparent protective eyelid slides away- Revealing iris and slit pupil, glinting wetly-- The pupil dilates, focuses-- The lights come back on. The pupil contracts. The eye BLI 11.
(re: the lights) About time... Keith turns back to the beast. Its eye tracks his movemen Keith's own eyes go wide.

Good lord-- And then the earth shakes again as the beast's head moves Claws tear out of the earth-- One whole section of wall undulates--and we become aware the monster's tail is wrapped around the entire cavern-- Sections of the ladder tear loose. Climbers plunge to ear The mouth closes, then opens again. FIRE fills the cavern And there is a DISTINCTIVE ROAR, sharp and terrifying, un anything anyone has ever heard--

Jill peers into a microscope--and suddenly the building s She braces for it to pass. It doesn't. It gets worse. The door slams open. A Radio Man scrambles to a radio nea Jill. Fluorescent lights flicker, strobing the room.
What's going on-- The whole room tips, upending cabinets and shelves. Jill pinned beneath a table.

Mayday! Mayday! This is Arctic Outpost--  13 A beam collapses, slamming into him, silencing him. The r still shaking. Jill tries to push the cabinet off of her, it is too heavy. She looks toward the window, and GASPS-- Despite her obscured view of the window in the half-colla wall, she sees: The two rows of huge, gleaming jagged teeth, moving past past and past for much longer than one would expect.
My god... And then the building is jarred again, and the ceiling COLLAPSES, and the flickering lights flicker off. 12.

Heavy winds and rain: a HURRICANE. A small fishing villag battens down for the storm. Waves lash across the docks. One villager, JUNJI, looks out from his house. Moored boa bang against the docks. Villagers hurry to cover, past th stacked on the wharf. One boat's lines have come loose; it is in danger of gett swamped. JUNJI gasps: it is his boat. JUNJI'S WIFE appears in the doorway behind him, drawn by gasp. She sees the boat. Junji starts to leave the house- His wife stops him with a hand on his shoulder.
(in Japanese) Don't go out there--you'll drown!

(in Japanese) Without my boat, I have no life! He stares at her, adamant. She nods, resigned--but gestur him to wait. Disappears into the house. Reappears with a bright yellow slicker. She helps Junji into it. He gives a kiss, then ducks into the storm. She watches him go. LIGHTNING scrabbles across the dark heavy clouds. Junji h  14 to his boat. Struggles to make the line fast. From out in the ocean, the village looks very small, very fragile. And then something rises out of the waves, block the village. Huge with jagged dorsal fins: Godzilla. On the docks, a SOUND rises above the storm: the DISTINCT ROAR. Junji looks up-- There is a FLASH OF LIGHTNING. Between Junji and the ligh the huge shape continues to rise-- Junji stares up in horror and shock. One huge, taloned fo crashes down, nearly on the small dock. And then the mons takes another step-- A dark shadow falls across Junji-- His wife watches, frozen with terror-- Junji falls back against the piling. The huge foot looms directly over him. He can see up, up, up the height of th body, the two arms, the serpentine neck. 13.

(in Japanese) It cannot be... (a certainty) Gojira... The foot descends--past him, miraculously sparing him. Other villagers see what's coming. Some run, some freeze, pray. Some race for the refuge of trees behind the villag The beast looms. One four-clawed hand reaches down-- --toward the villagers? Toward Junji? --Godzilla scoops up the entirety of the day's catch and tosses it into his gaping mouth, past enormous sharp teet His head turns toward the village. He moves, the earth sh beneath his tread. Junji's wife stares up as he nears-- Junji screams from the docks--

(in Japanese) Run! Run! --but she can't hear. Godzilla's foot comes down-- --crushing the house. Junjits eyes go hollow. He stares now, a mad witness.  15 Godzilla's tail drags across the village, causing more destruction. More villagers are buried beneath the wrecka But Godzilla pays them no heed. He reaches for the windswept forest behind the village, s huge furrow in the ground, uprooting an entire copse of t He raises it to his mouth--and two villagers who were hid shake loose, plummet to the ground. Godzilla gulps down t trees. He moves back toward the ocean--then pauses. Cranes his h back, looking up into the sky, searching for something-- The clouds blow apart briefly, revealing the night sky, e save for twinkling stars. The clouds close. Lightning cra GODZILLA ROARS and BREATHES FIRE. A warning. A challenge. And then he goes to all fours and dives into the sea, his bulk moving past Junji impossibly fast. Godzilla's 150-fo tail sweeps around, creating a huge wave-- The wave CRASHES across the island, hurling ships over do smashing through houses-- Junji clings to a piling for his life. The water sweeps b somehow, Junji holds on. He stares out at the sea--
Where the monster sinks down, disappearing into the viole storm-tossed ocean.
The ocean. Calm now. On a bluff above the ocean a road pa beneath a high, ugly wall, topped with barbed wire.

A car veers off the road. Two men get out: AARON VAUGHT. Tall, graceful, eyes watchful behind wire-r glasses. He looks like a ski instructor who chucked it al become a librarian. MARTY KENOSHITA, enthusiastic, bordering on intense. He large trial case. Aaron steps up on the hood of the car, then to the roof, him a view across the top of the wall-- Beyond the barbed wire is not the expected prison. Instea there are manicured tea gardens, small cottages. A koi po beneath lovely waterfalls. All that betrays the illusion luxury hotel is the wall, surrounding the grounds on thre sides. The bluff is the fourth barrier. Marty scrambles up next to Aaron.
There he is. (points) Staring at the ocean. Across the grounds, a figure sits.
Maybe he is crazy, like they say.
Yeah, and maybe not. If you wanted to hide someone, keep them quiet, this would be a good place--
Marty, no paranoia tonight. (gestures) Loan me your coat. Marty frowns, but slips off his overcoat. 15. Aaron tosses it onto the wall, covering the barbed wire.
Aaron tosses his pack into the grounds. Leaps to the wall swings over. A beat; Marty heaves his case over, follows.
Marty and Aaron near the seated figure-- It is Junji--looking much older than can be accounted for 16  17 time passed. He seems unaware of their presence, eyes sta out to sea.
Mr. Tange? Junji Tange? No response. Aaron nods to Marty. Marty translates what A says into Japanese, nearly simultaneously.

You're a hard man to find, Junji. We've been talking to survivors of the Taki Island Deluge for almost a year. Still no response. Marty adds something more in Japanese. his eyes, Aaron inquires ‘what?!
I said they all tell the same story: the worst hurricane in fifty years virtually washed away one of the chain. Aaron nods, steps closer to Junji. Marty still translates
But there are also stories of a man who saw a giant dragon. A dragon that breathed fire and made tidal waves. He waits. Nothing. He sighs-- --and then Junji speaks. Marty translates to English:
A storm killed my wife. And I am a crazy man that no one believes. 16.
(Marty translating) Every culture has myths about dragons. The Midgard Serpent, Quetzacoatl. The dragon that sleeps at the heart of the world... (beat) Only I don't think they're just stories.  18

(in Japanese) He even wrote a book about it. Before Aaron can stop him, Marty pulls out an oversized paperback, hands it to Junji. Aaron's photo is on the back cover. Junji looks from it t Aaron. Aaron, a little sheepish, strikes the same pose, s the same smile. Junji turns the book over. His eyes widen "THE WAKING DRAGON' by Aaron Vaught. The cover is an old print of a dragon; it vaguely resembles Godzilla. Junji hurriedly opens the book to a photo: an Aztec hieroglyph Quetzacoatl, again Godzilla-like. Junji flips through the book, becoming more excited with photograph, each reproduced drawing. He pauses-- CLOSE ON: an Assyrian carving of a dragon and a gryphon, around each other, locked in combat.
(Marty translating) I believe in dragons, Junji. Junji looks up at him--then stands suddenly, and hurries carrying Aaron's book. Aaron and Marty follow.

Aaron and Marty's car sits near the wall. Suddenly illumi high-powered flashlight beams. POLICEMEN swarm in. One cl to the roof, pulls Marty's coat off the wall. Displays it PIKE, wearing a scowl he was born with. He stands in fron two other AMERICAN AGENTS. All wear sharply-tailored blac suits and no-nonsense expressions. Pike rolls his neck, a characteristic tic, CRACKING it. Gestures for the police to move in-- 17.
Simple in design: futon, low table, bath screened off. Junji looks around conspiratorially, loosens a floorboard

(in Japanese)  19 The doctors would take these if they knew-- He reaches into a space beneath the floor, digs out sheav paper. They spill toward Aaron, a flood of paper-- --drawings of Godzilla. Hundreds. Aaron and Marty sift th them, moving carefully to not step on them. Junji speaks excitedly; Marty listens, translate for Aaron:

He says he dreams of it. Remembers stories from his grandfather. About the people before people. Stories about-- Junji holds up a drawing. Painted on it are the three Jap Katakana characters for Godzilla.
Gojira. Marty whips out a PDA, writes down the name.
Have we ever indexed that name?

No--wait, yes...In 1928, Atkinson translated the characters as...Godzilla-- He cuts himself off. A particular drawing has caught his He kneels beside it, staring. Aaron joins him. It is a painting. A _gryphon, curled into a fetal positio a mound beneath the earth. Godzilla breathing fire on it.

The adversary? Aaron nods, picks it up-- Suddenly, two uniformed POLICEMAN burst into the cottage. move toward Aaron and Marty, who back away. Aaron folds t paper, slips it into his pocket. Junji, panicked, crawls, picking up his drawings, holding to his chest. A DOCTOR and several ATTENDANTS enter. 18.  20
(to Aaron) You are trespassing. And you have upset my patient. (in Japanese) (re: the drawings) He should not have these. The Attendants begin gathering up the drawings.
You can't take those away-- The police escort Aaron and Marty roughly to the door--
Outside, agent Pike stands, flanked by his agents. He fla his credentials at Aaron:
Pike, National Security Council. You'll want to come with us. (to the police) Thank you, gentlemen. We'll take them from here.
(to Marty) Did I call you paranoid? I apologize. The Attendants escort Junji away. Junji twists free. In b English, to Aaron:
I am not a crazy who sees things-- (beat) I am crazy because of what I saw! Aaron regards him. The two men lock eyes.
I believe you. Junji looks relieved. His mouth trembles into a slight sm grateful for being believed. Aaron and Marty are escorted Junji sadly, resignedly, watches them go.

The pickup pulls up at a gas station/cafe, next to a sher 4X, Two ranch hands, JOHN and STU, get out. The Collie ju down. Sniffs the air, heads out toward the road.
Hold it a second. He pauses in front of the truck, lights up a Pall Mall.
(an old complaint) Goddammit, Stu, when you gonna quit? (Stu ignores him) And aren't you supposed to smoke after you eat? Stu takes a satisfying drag, grins.
It's whatcha call an appetizer. The Collie suddenly STOPS. Makes a low GROWL toward the s Then it starts to HOWL--

Grazing HORSES raise their heads, look around, nervous. VULTURES on a gnarled branch edge sideways, then swoop aw A crawling LIZARD stops, tilts its head. A COYOTE howls. SNAKE coils defensively. A MOUNTAIN LION leaps atop a rock outcropping, surveys th desert floor. Then, suddenly startled, it crouches down, up over its shoulder--

huge, blazing, blindingly white. At its center, barely noticeable at first, is a tiny black dot...growing larger  22 approaches. Soon it ECLIPSES the sun...it is an ALIEN PRO hurtling toward us, taking us into DARKNESS-- The Coyote backs up several steps. The horses move closer together, rubbing past each other, spooked. The lizard sc away-- In the sky, the Alien Probe ROARS, a BALL OF FIRE now as through the air downward-- 20. The horses bolt. The Mountain Lion SNARLS--

A quiet, remote lake. On the surface is the reflection of approaching Probe. It grows larger-- --and then the Alien Probe SLAMS into the lake; TONS of w are DISPLACED. The rest HISSES, BOILS, churning upwards i CURTAIN OF STEAM. Nearby treetops EXPLODE INTO FLAME--

Wind-blown snow washes across the familiar icy landscape. SOLDIER trudges toward one of a cluster of shacks that si the edge of the gaping crevice of Godzilla's womb. Suddenly a low RUMBLE builds to a deep, rending GRINDING The Soldier turns: in the distance a PILLAR OF LIGHT shoo toward the sky. The light emerges from a huge CRACK in the ice. A GLOWING CHAMBER pushes up, cutting through the ice. It is dome-sh a series of huge bubbles arranged in the regular/irregula pattern of a Mandlebrot equation. The Soldier backs away from it...turns and RUNS toward a building--so fast he slips, falls hard on the ice. He get pulls open the door--
The Soldier flips on the radio, grabs the mic.
Nome, this is Outpost 42--come in! Jesus, come in--  23 The radio emits a HIGH-PITCHED SQUEAL. He clicks the dial SQUEAL covers all channels--

In the cafe window, the corner-mounted television flips t static. We hear the same HIGH-PITCHED SQUEAL. Outside, the Collie darts between John's legs, under the Cigarette smoke drifts toward John; he waves at it.
Haven't you ever heard of second- hand smoke? 21.
Yeah, you ever hear of a second- hand ass-kicking? That's when I think about hitting you so hard, you feel it-- WHACK! Suddenly, for no apparent reason, John is knocked Stu stares.
Huh. Guess I wasn't kidding.

What the hell hit me? Stu looks, points: a mangled frog, dazed, lies beside Joh sTU Someone shot a frog at you. BANG! Another frog bounces off the roof of the truck. Ano one SLAPS down onto the street.

Shit--they're shootin' frogs at both of us! And then comes the DELUGE: Rain, frogs and fish pour down the darkened skies. They BANG off the corrugated tin roof of the cafe. The 4X siren light bar SHATTERS. Stu and John leap into the pick  24 The Sheriff exits the cafe, hand on gun. A roly-poly WAIT follows. They stare as: Frogs and fish plummet, breaking windshields. Electricity CRACKLES as telephone wires are snapped. Beneath the pick frightened Collie looks out at the madness.

Like in the bible...A plague is being visited on us. It's a sign of the millennium... On a store porch, NELSON FLEER appears. The sign above advertises: Wilderness Guide/Cave Diving/ Prospecting/Nel Fleer, Prop. A tall, athletic man, Fleer carries a dive t one hand, a wrench in the other. The rain of frogs and fishes slowly abates. The Sheriff m into the street, hand still on his gun, peering warily up sky, and stepping gingerly. Fish gasp and flop. Some frog twitch, the less mangled ones try to hop.
Damn. I hate weird shit. 22. He sees a dead frog on the rail. Flicks it; it flops to t ground. A final glance at the sky, then Fleer ducks insid
(starts to pray) Oh, God. Grant us strength to overcome our sins that displeased you...
(a sigh) Grant us strength to clean this mess up. A SQUISH as he missteps. He lifts his leg to check the bo of his shoe, curses.
Aaron and Marty wait in the plush lounge, uncomfortable. Special Agent Pike enters, extends a thick file.

Here. You're to familiarize  25 yourself with these materials. Puzzled, Aaron takes the file. On the front is a logo: an armored gauntlet holding a sword. Emblazoned with the wor GEORGE PROJECT. Stamped TOP SECRET. Aaron opens the folder. His eyes widen. Marty leans in, o his shoulder-- The first page is a photo of Godzilla's head as he was fo half-buried in ice. A bio-suited figure gives it scale. A flips back to the cover.
The St. George Project? Grinning, Pike tilts his head, CRACKS his neck.
Mr. Vaught, your government would like to offer you a job.
Imbedded in a conference table is the gauntlet-and-sword the St. George Project. Aaron's book 'The Waking Dragon' tossed, lands on the logo.
This is unacceptable. It's... it's...an insult to the work that we've done. 23.
ADMIRAL TIMOTHY BENEDEK sits at the head of the table. Hi carved laugh lines contrast with his razor cut bearing.
Concerns have been raised about the lack of results. I cut a deal to keep your funding. ED, a scientist wearing trademark white T-shirt, leans ba the table, frustrated.
(spits out the word) Politics.

Your feelings, Dr. Llewellyn? At the far end of the table, a FIGURE sits in shadow, hid from view. The FIGURE stands into the light-- --and we reveal not Keith Llewellyn, as expected, but his Jill. The time passed has not diminished the passion in h but events have darkened it, given it a steely edge.
If he's being groomed for my job, I want to know it.
Vaught will start in an advisory role. If that gets results, there won't be need for any further changes. Jill considers this.
I'll think about it.
Think fast--he's on his way.
Pike puts his palm on a palm-lock, peers into a retina sc Aaron and Marty glance at each other nervously. Door locks UNCLAMP. Pike steps through--

Aaron and Marty follow Pike into the situation room. Glas walls surround a combination of mission control and a sci lab. 26  To store the beastie--if we ever find it. (grins) Dr. Llewellyn calls it the dissection tank-- At the far end of the room, Jill bursts through a door, a Benedek follows her.
The man has drawn some correct conclusions--
He's made lucky guesses. Aaron Vaught is no scientist. He's a folklorist who believes in the lost continent of Atlantis. He's a crackpot.
He's a popular crackpot. The President has read that book-- Jill speaks to Benedek, oblivious to Aaron's presence:

Listen. Vaught wants to...to collect this thing. To index it. To write books about it and earn lecture fees talking about it and pose for goddamn photos with it. (fierce) I just want to kill it. So you see, there is a conflict.

I think it's for you. He turns the phone to Jill. ON SCREEN: A MILITARY POLICE OFFICER, wearing a white MP helmet and a scowl. Jill rolls her eyes. She knows what its about.

If she continues to be... unmanageable, you and she will be expelled from base housing.  26.
I think that's her plan.

There is nothing here for me, mom. Just a bunch of grunts and eggheads. No offense.
(icy) None taken.
You should let me go live with Aunt Julia--
I'm not having this argument again. This is where my job is. Ergo, this is where you are.
I'm sick of this place! I'm sick of army brats and the MPs and the PX...and I'm sick of green. There isn't even a mall anywhere nearby...
Oh, as though you're going to go hang at a mall.
(smiles) Well...okay. Right on that. She regards Jill, considering something. Proceeds warily.
But...I'm not just thinking of me. I'm really not. I'm...I'm worried about you, mom. Jill glances at her. This is of real concern to Tina.
I think you need to get out of this place, too. I don't think its good for you. 29  30 She gauges Jill's reaction. So far, so good. Takes a deep breath, plunges ahead: 27.
Ever since Dad died, you've...you changed, okay? Maybe we didn't always get along, but--
Do not pursue this, Tina. And do not blame our difficulties on...on that.

I'm not! Jeez, you can't even talk about it. Obviously a vulnerable spot for Jill. She looks away. A l silence in the car. They both stare out the front windshi Tears well up in Tina's eyes. Quell surprise. The car's headlights sweep across Tina, and then she is a the darkened porch.

Send it south for testing. I want to know if it is the same. She looks over, notices Aaron staring at a crumpled, fold paper: Junji's drawing. He looks from it to the cavern.

Hm? Oh...uh...it's common in mythology for  (shrugs; forges ahead) For the great dragons to have opponents...adversaries. Sometimes it's a sun-king, sometimes another monster-- (for instance) In the Bible, Leviathan and

Except this place. This place is...special, somehow. Jill stares at them. Jill takes

troubled--she almost agrees with Pike.
